content.body: Lachy - regarding the page, I've added questions to the one Pro item of the sort that I think should be asked about Pro and Con items of any particular proposed solution.
tantek, yeah, I intend to provide that info. There's some notes about it in the esw wiki and others I've seen in the mail archives that I will have to find
sicking: do you think we should require SQL support?
Hixie: philip.html5.org is more recent, and less of a random meaningless domain
k
jgraham: The cost of the ifs seems pretty irrelevant in overall html5lib performance, so it doesn't really seem like an interesting thing to optimise, if I remember correctly
Changing e.g. the way it looks at content model flag doesn't seem to affect much either
(I think I tried making an extremely stripped down tokeniser that basically parses < and tag names and > and data, or something like that, and it was quite similarly slow to html5lib)
notes that Alton Towers has nice rollercoasters
Hixie: are you comparing requiring SQL with requiring Theora?
would be fine with sql if there were general agreement upon some rigorous specification of exact syntax and behavior
which doesn't seem likely to happen given the enormity of the prerequisite tasks, but is not entirely unlikely
roc: well, a lot of the arguments sicking makes seem to apply equally to ignoring mozilla's preference and requiring support for the sql database api
The arguments seem completely different to me
in each case, the argument for inclusion would be to promote interoperability by exerting market pressure on holdouts
but the reasons for people holding out are completely different
so your Mozilla's reasons for holding out are valid but Apple's are not?
Modulo my limited understanding of Apple's reasons --- yes.
if Web SQL was the only plausible solution for structured client-side storage, I'm sure we'd just bite the bullet and do it.
so existence of plausible (though not yet materialized) alternatives justifies holding out, in a way that specs should accomodate?
depends on what you mean by "materialized"
http://hg.toolness.com/browser-couch/raw-file/blog-post/index.html
there are many other differences between the two situations
fundamentally, i don't think i should be in the business of saying that apple's reasons are less good than mozilla's reasons
in particular, not when it won't make any difference anyway
as in this case

e.g., only one browser implements Web SQL currently, so there's no interop to speak of, whereas we have three browsers with demoed or shipping Theora implementations, one of which is actually different code
there's the issue of Web SQL not having a real spec
Right now we have 1 browser shipping it and 2 that have publicly committed to doing so
Has Opera committed to it?
vs for Theora, 2 browsers shipping and 1 publicly committed
Opera has said they will do it
(websql will have a real spec after html5 is in last call, assuming no better alternatives surface -- i'll write it myself if i have to :-) )
othermaciej: OK, that strengthens the case for Web SQL a bit.
I think Mozilla is entitled to wait and see what happens, even if I would prefer you did implement Web SQL
that's why I proposed splitting it from the rest of the Web Storage spec
I doubt we'll see an independent implementation of SQLite's SQL dialect, though, which remains a worry
i think mozilla's concerns with websql are perfectly valid
i think apple's concerns with theora are valid too
insofar as mozilla thinks their concerns are valid, and apple thinks their concerns are valid
fwiw Apple is doing a new round of research on the matter
I don't think we should shy away from making value judgements about peoples' concerns
people have unreasonable concerns sometimes
I know it can sound arrogant
that's a very dangerous path to go down, imho
and not one that leads to productive cooperation
what would you do if i said that mozilla's concerns re websql weren't valid?
i doubt you would really appreciate it
We'd argue about it
in the past I've had a lot of concerns that you have assuaged in one way or another
I don't think I personally, or Mozilla in general, am immune to unrealistic or overblown concerns
putting them on an untouchable pedestal is itself dangerous
i'm talking specifically about "we won't implement X" feedback
for more nuanced feedback, things are more complex
I think the only thing anyone has done to assuage Apple's concerns (or Google's) about Theora is to say they shouldn't count or imply that they are not on the level
Mozilla has not said "we won't implement SQL"
at least, I don't think we have
not quite as explicitly as apple has said it about theora, i'll grant you

anyway, my point was just that sicking's comments seemed to be dangerously close to saying "ignore apple", which i don't think it would be appropriate for me to do, as i think it would set a precedent for ignoring any vendor whose feedback isn't convenient.
which could be mozilla, e.g. as with websql
i'm just trying to treat everyone fairly :-)
othermaciej: there's an interesting thing. Google's got concerns about Theora not being a great codec. Fine. But they're implementing it anyway. I don't understand why Apple can't do the same.
othermaciej: or at least, patents are the only reason I can understand.
our concerns are that we could get sued, and that it might not be viable on the phone
we're going to investigate both these issues much more in depth
roc, btw, here's the message from MS on SQL dialects:
http://groups.google.com/group/mozilla.community.web-standards/msg/d6a92db27bd52bcb
"viable" as in "consumes more power than your H.264 hardware decoder" or as in "Will Not Work At All"?
the former is a red herring, I think.
I wouldn't phrase it in as absolute a way as you just did
the latter would be a shock
vlc plays theora videos on jailbroken iphones so it's certainly possible
One question in the mega-thread that I asked that never got answered is "how would supporting Theora make the iPhone *worse*"?
"viable" as in "consumes more power than seems reasonable" and "renders at adequate performance relative to the quality of experience we expect on iPhone OS"
er
I phrased one of those backwards
does Apple reject applications from the iPhone store because they run the CPU at 100%?
"doesn't consume more power than seems reasonable"
does Safari refuse to render Web pages that run too much JS?
we do limit background apps in part to avoid killing the battery
and yes, MobileSafari has a JS execution limit
what sort of limit?
run JS for too long within a given time period and it gets shut off for that page
ok
I wonder what Opera thinks about this mobile power issue
since that's most of their business
anyway, to clarify the parameters, if it took 10x as much battery that would probably be unacceptable, if it took 1.5x, that probably wouldn't be
the camera app on the iphone consumes an enormous amount of power - so does skype. Ban them imho.
anyway I think it needs to be put to the test whether a software-only implementation could be acceptable
I suspect Opera cares less, because it's the device vendor, not the app vendor, who faces the users' ire over poor battery life
I suspect device vendors are able to forward that feedback
roc, anyway, I think the SQL comparison is not such a good. I don't think the storage draft has a dangling dependency.
sayrer_: it's worse, it has a dependency on something that doesn't exist, a spec for SQLite
well, if the storage draft contains SQL
if it's moved into a new Web SQL API draft, that document still has it
right, that could be fixed. I believe Ian when he says he'll fix it if necessary. But we can't be blamed for pushing back against the draft that exists today
no-one really knows how hard it will be to spec out the SQL bit. I have faith in Ian's supreme speccing skills, that's all
roc, I read the response as saying the splitting of the storage spec was due to our lack of implementation
but it seems to me that splitting the spec is not really the same as leaving something unspecified
roc: :-)
wishes hsivonen were not in a time zone that's still somewhat asleep right now
reads the .web-standards newsgroup posts
hates Hates HATES how threading is utterly destroyed by the unholy mailing list-newsgroup chimera the mirroring software creates
anybody know of GUI alternative to ssh-keygen?
MikeSmith: PuTTYGen, on Windows.
kinetik: thanks
kinetik: know if there's any equivalent for OSX?
I got an request by e-mail for info about generating a keypair, and don't know if he's on Windows or Mac
and no clue personally because I've never used anything but ssh-keygen myself
SSHKeychain, I *think*
send him http://github.com/guides/providing-your-ssh-key ?
it has instructions for win/mac/linux
jwalden: I find something called "SSH Agent" (not so great a name, since there's the ssh-agent CLI tool)
gavin_: great, thanks
http://www.sshkeychain.org/ was what I referred to
jwalden: OK
comment enough in <https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=472529>, Hixie?  :-P
wonders what happens if Microsoft announce that they will never support <canvas> or that they will never replace their non-tree-like DOM
I think we're OK in the latter case

hober: afaict Hixie's arguments about requiring vendor consensus means that we would have to either a) get everyone else to agree to the IE model or b) leave a big chunk of the parsing mechanism unspecified
My understanding is that the cases in which IE's DOM is a non-tree aren't important for web compat
which is how the other browsers have gotten away with not reverse-engineering it
hober: Indeed. But that seems to me to be a more nuanced position than Hixie has taken.
(possibly because the examples that have actually come up have not required it)
jwalden: I'm awake now
hsivonen: aha!
hsivonen: so most people on planet have full-text feeds there
dunno if that was intentional or not, but it's a rather marked difference from most of the other posts
jwalden: My full text feed has the full text for the latest entry and the most recent entries from 24 hours
jwalden: unless there's a bug, of course
hm
jwalden: the older entries only get summaries and typically don't show up on planets anyway after initial setup
jwalden: though the other planets I'm on are actually Venus
in case that makes a difference
well, at least validation 2.0 and large-amount-of-finnish-I-can't read are showing up in google reader without a body
jwalden: but the latest entry in the Atom feed has full text, right?
(I should rewrite my feed generator anyway. the current one uses severely legacy software and I can't touch it without breaking it)

hm, I think so; I have auto-send-me-elsewhere in all the browsers I can test directly now, view-source: suggests yes but there's no formatting, so it's hard to say (wonder if mime type is wrong maybe)
works on Planet Intertwingly
maybe the Planet Mozilla view becomes normal once I update when planet is already subscribing
unless the version of planet at Planet Mozilla is so old that it can't deal with XHTML-in-Atom
hsivonen: I see the full text of "
An Unofficial Q&A about the Discontinuation of the XHTML2 WG" on planet.mozilla.org
oh. right. now I see it too.
I have no idea why the old posts appear after it
after in time
before in page order
oh, and planet.mozilla.org says it's running Venus
so things should go normal with the next update
hopefully
heh
hsivonen: Write a short article about using the hml5 parser in nightlies so we can find out :)
jgraham: I will once comment end bang is on m-c
jgraham: since not having it known to be a compat issue, so there's no point in inviting reports about not having it breaking pages
me things that "comment end bang" is a nice name for something
jgraham: like "spurious triples"
jgraham: i don't know what we would do if we couldn't get consensus on something as core as parsing
http://www.sandisk.com/Products/Catalog%281433%29-Players_bundles.aspx is interesting with the HTML5 parsing algorithm
hsivonen: the squares at the bottom of your pages always confuse me
i always think they're an image that failed to load
and spent 10 seconds each time interacting with them
Hixie: do you mean the dingbat that I use for <hr>?
yeah
Hixie: it's a PUA glyph. you need @font-face supporting UA :-)
i have one
two even
still looks like a square :-)
Hixie: interesting. which UA and which platform?
mac os x, safari and firefox nightlies
actually i haven't tried firefox
works in firefox
that sandisk page is sad
any idea what's wrong yet?
Hixie: I think it's
Hixie: but further than that, I don't know yet
k
Hixie: Safari WFM with the font installed locally. Apple makes it too hard to test Safari with @font-face if you have the font file anywhere on disk
Hixie: and Parallels is too scared of Apple to let me run a clean VM
i wish safari would show your content before the ttf file downloaded
firefox's flickering experience is actually nicer, imho
I suppose I could uninstall the font *and* go zipping all instances of the font files around all mounted volumes so that Safari couldn't detect the presence of the font on disk
Hixie: I wish hyatt agreed with you
maybe I'll just take a look the next time I visit another Mac user who doesn't have the font locally
hsivonen: WFM in firefox / opera on Linux
jgraham: which page? http://www.sandisk.com/Products/Catalog%281433%29-Players_bundles.aspx ?
what would I see in the browser if that page not being rendered as expected?
replacement characters or artifacts on the page somewhere?
MikeSmith: No hsivonen's funky pua thing
ah
MikeSmith: The sandisk page breaks for me in firefox with html5.enable
(look at the top menu)
jgraham: oh. re-reading the scrollback now, I see that's what hsivonen mentioned
got confused

The sandisk issue minimizes to
  • A
      B

Hixie, re http://lists.whatwg.org/pipermail/whatwg-whatwg.org/2009-July/020783.html - you mentioned you're going to be taking out the SQL stuff from webstorage. Will it be replaced by something else, or just progress in its own spec?
Lachy: separate spec for now
Lachy: maybe other specs will be introduced to compete with it
we'll see
Is it ok to ask short html5 questions here, or is this channel about the spec process?
Creap: both
ok
though this is often a bitch channel so you might not get useful replies :-)
Also, it's just a social channel damnit :P
isn't that just IRC overall :)
hsivonen: weird. The PUA wfm on Arora on Linux (built against Webkit trunk) but not in latest Chrome (191)
well, I'm considering having a fieldset with a meter measuring how secure a password a user has entered is, and some text on how to improve it. technically it's not a form element..
maybe if I combine it with an output?
hsivonen: maybe beause Arora is QtWebkit, Chrome is GTK+
Hixie, have you explained what will happen with the SQL stuff in more detail, elsewhere?
like in any mail I may have skipped in public-webapps?
no
bu tthere's no much to explain
i just plan to split web storage into two, web storage and web database
ok
Hixie: for now, I'm treating the PUA thing as a bug that should be fixed in WebKit rather than fixing it in my CSS
hsivonen: wow, weird. i thought IE ignored altogether. send mail, we should be able to fix that.
Hixie: this is interesting: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms533020%28VS.85%29.aspx#Close_Your_Tags
what's the reason for splitting it? Is it because it's not clear whether the SQL stuff has an uncertain future?
hsivonen: btw if you could comment on mjs' idea of introducing a third level of conformance (summary being conforming but showing a warning) that would be useful
let me rephrase...
hsivonen: hmm, even http://sandisk.com page looks equally porked with html5.enable
hsivonen: (on the list, about to go to bed)
... Is it because the SQL stuff has an uncertain future?
Hixie: assuming that the MSDN article has been written by someone who actually knows IE internals
Lachy: main reason is because they are independent features, and might have different lifecycles
ok
Hixie: I haven't read list email today. I'll get to it.
Lachy: but the uncertain future and the weirdness from the oracle guy were further motivating factors
I'll get to it some time, not now that is.
hsivonen: no rush, but i'm holding off on replying to mjs pending your input
looking at msdn page...
Creap: <meter> would be appropriate for that in html5
Creap: not supported anywhere yet of course
Creap: <output> would be fine too
nope, but since javascript will be required anyway, I might as well use meter with attributes for visual hints, for instance, if value is lower than 'low' then make the text red
hsivonen: if that's written by someone who knows their parser, that's a frightening insight into what their code does
hsivonen: There seems to be a typo in your bug report
hsivonen: I guess http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7084 should say <ul>, not <iul>
shakes his fist at jgraham
laughs, manically
Oh, and there's a </l>
I guess some accidental drag&drop moved the i around
jgraham: Also amazingly silently for manic laughter
http://slashdot.org/pollBooth.pl?qid=1813&aid=-1
jd found stackoverflow and got downvoted.
hsivonen: link?
gsnedders: http://stackoverflow.com/users/133893/john-dowdell
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1086886/html-5-video-tag-vs-flash-video-what-are-the-pros-and-cons/1089156#1089156 is his one and only comment
krijnh: More logs?
For #webapps, dont' know
Still gotta put yours online, but they're on a different machine atm :)
And reformat them, I bet :)
Nah, why? :)
You don't seem to be on w3c-irc right now, so I can hold off sending them until you're back stable
I'm not?
Well, the logs I sent you include the control characters for colors and stuff
Ah, I'm not :p
http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/webapps/20090707#l-25
I don't think those characters are a problem
Well, if you want user modes you have to translate the nick colors :)
Since I use color coding instead of mode prefixes
Hixie: do Microsoft and Nokia count as browser vendors who have veto on spec sections?
wow. spammers have developed networks of hundreds of inter-following spam twitter accounts
hsivonen, link?
I wonder how that's useful for spammers
pm'ed link to avoid driving traffic to spammers
from krijn's logs, that is
Doesn't this channel have the comment feature?
ah. right. what was it?
I don't know
Dashiva, what feature are you referring to?
We could check the logs - oh wait :)
Lachy: the one developed for webapps WG
#off, but it doesn't work here
Dashiva: I don't think it does
it's [off] but it doesn't work here
krijnh: ah. ok
Of [off]
hsivonen: is it really surprising?
virtuelv: well, not really
virtuelv: I'm not surprised that there are spam accounts
virtuelv: I'm mildly surprised about them taking the time to arrange follower numbers
I'd call it "two degrees of Google"
while twitter uses nofollow, I think the ultimate purpose is to get people to create the links elsewhere
and twitter drives significant traffic to a site on its own
http://trac.webkit.org/changeset/43972 is a great example of why hasFeature() kind of APIs don't work on the Web
Isn't hasFeature pretty much relegated to Java use?
I don't know
maybe the return values should be "maybe" and "maybeNot"
Has anyone ever actually used the HTML DOM in Java, and do they still?
Dashiva: hasFeature has been considered for widgets
(where by "HTML DOM" I mean the parts that aren't used for generic XML)
is unaware of what contexts it would be used in
oh. great. now Dr. Nielsen's expertise *can* be questioned :-)
because let's say you specify <feature name="http://example.com/directbraininterface">, and configuration disallows it, you might just want to know
Philip`: Isn't hasFeature a generic part of DOM?
Dashiva: document.implementation.hasFeature, yes
DOM1
hsivonen: Maybe the return value should just be "maybe"
http://grack.com/blog/2009/07/07/video-support-for-older-browsers/
jgraham: "maybe" and "false"
or "no way in hell"
virtuelv: "buggy" and "false" seems more accurate
opera friends, please help me out
I see http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2009/07/03/crash-logging-on-the-mac says there is a new snapshot build
MikeSmith, with what?
MikeSmith: ...
Lachy, jgraham - I have opera:config#AutoUpdate|DownloadAllSnapshots set to on
but when I do "Check for updates"
can see where this is going and the answer is "I don't know"
it tells me I'm running the latest version
heh
MikeSmith, you'll want to ask someone from Desktop, I think
I can of course ask if Lachy or someone doesn't know
well, if you know who does know, feel free to PM me with a name, and I'll bug them instead
Lachy: Can I leave this to you? All the desktop people are in Oslo...
MikeSmith, I will relay your question to #staff
MikeSmith, I was given this as the response:
http://my.opera.com/desktopteam/blog/2009/07/03/crash-logging-on-the-mac?startidx=150#comment9311695
Lachy: I see. well, please convey to Rijk (or Olli or Claudio or somebody) that perhaps it's time they might want to get around to spending some time making it a "push one button" operation
MikeSmith, feel free to email them or comment on the desktop team blog about that
http://www.appleinsider.com/articles/09/07/06/ogg_theora_h_264_and_the_html_5_browser_squabble.html
Lachy: oh great. Apple enthusiasts joining the 'debate'
for the most part, it's a reasonable article, except for a few bogus claims about Opera near the end
I like the historical point of view
Lachy: well, up front they say " Ogg Theora, commercially abandoned nearly a decade ago, doesn't have what it takes to deliver video on the increasingly mobile web"
and it seems to reject Ogg Theora as "commercially abandoned nearly a decade ago,"
yeah
oh, and they also repeat Google's claim about it's inability to use Ogg Theora due to bandwidth issues, without mentioning that claim itself is highly questionable
they also claim that Apple can't bet on Theora because of submarine patents but H264 may have the same problems
it has an Apple press flavor where you assume that whatever Apple is doing with the iPhone is right and then construct arguments not to contradict that assumption
or explaining how great move it is to go glossy with displays

Rik|work, sure, there's always a chance that h.264 has some submarine patents applying to it that haven't yet surfaced, but given that it's been out for so long with so much industry support, and that none have surfaced yet, it's becoming more and more unlikely
also, the article totally misses the point regarding patents and GPLed software produced outside the U.S. and not shipped commercially
glossy displays with sufficient anti-reflective coating may not be too bad. The glossy display on my iMac has no problems
Lachy: That article is so far from npov it cannot be described as "reasonable"
Though, I haven't yet used a laptop with a glossy display, in enough places to judge
Lachy: my data points are that the built-in display of my MacBook sucks horribly. (fortunately, I only use it while traveling)
Lachy: and my in-store experience with the latest Cinema Display is that it is unusably reflective
which is bad, because having to shop for an HP or Lenovo display is a pain
having to read technical details and stuff
and having to make compromises on how the enclosure fits into other decor
the problem with in-store experience is that it doesn't quite match real world conditions
They should let you borrow monitors and take them home to test them in real world conditions
the store had a window
the real world has a window, too
The real world has many windows
meanwhile, the old 30" Cinema Display was great in the same store under the same harsh conditions
harsh as in having a window!
with sunlight
next time I'm in an apple store, I will take a look at their displays
which should, hopefully, be some time this week, assuming they finally repair my iMac
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.UnsupportedClassVersionError: Bad version number in .class file
haven't had that problem with JDK 5 before
maybe the world has started to move on to 6 now
hsivonen: Is hsivonen.iki.fi down?
hsivonen: Oh, it worked now
Philip`: just really slow
hsivonen: Okay
(I don't know why. It's a shared host.)
My legacy scripts depending on PyGenx are inconvenient to move to another host
lesson: never depend of C-backed python modules that aren't available via apt
http://www.ibiblio.org/jwrobie/blog/?p=120 (via Julian)
"I would like to see the XHTML Working Group finish their work, and I would like to see the result used as the XML serialization of HTML5"
http://www.zeldman.com/2009/07/07/in-defense-of-web-developers/
I don't understand why zeldman loves xhtml so much
what does it provide over html4 ?
It encourages prettier syntax
Is there some web server or proxy that can be configured to return 503 if there are more than n simultaneous requests to the set of URIs matching some pattern?
right now I have trouble saying anything that wouldn't be snarky, and I've already been blamed for being snarky about XHTML-as-text/html
but it seems it's more in defense of gurus who promoted XHTML than in defense of the developers who followed them
It seems in defense of the tactics of picking a technology as the basis of a marketing platform that has little to do with the technology itself
welcome to the real world, aka not browsers, but people writing xhtml everywhere :)
i.e. using XHTML to promote clean semantic markup, similar to using AJAX to promote asynchronous updates, and similar to using HTML5 to promote web application APIs
"switching from HTML to XHTML was the perfect catharsis to leave behind not only the old syntax, but more important the old habits and practices of building a webpage"

Philip`: it is a discussion I already had with hsivonen in october 2007. XHTML exists. It is used. It is not served properly and not parsed by browsers as such, but people are writing xhtml in their editors. and it's what matters to them.
Philip`: yep, it helped people to look at the language in a different way.
the popularity of XHTML 1.0 Transitional doctype suggests a different thing
xhtml 1.0 transitional suggests: target ;)
But working again in a Web agency after a few years, I'm listening the people around me.

"[XHTML] taught a generation of developers what good code should or could look like. It was something that was always possible in HTML4 but XHTML1 helped train people to be more thoughtful and careful with their code. And in that sense, I think it was a success."

It seems that Zeldman's point is that promoting XHTML was good because he used it as a hook for the idea of promoting better semantics and structure, but that unfortuately gave rise to the myth that XHTML is somehow more semantic than HTML.
Lachy: Myths aren't necessarily bad
Philip`: indeed
they are when people use those myths to then promote XHTML as being better than HTML
Lachy: Why is that bad?
That argument sounds remarkably close to "people are too stupid to understand the full story so we have to present half truths instead"
because it attaches a stigma to HTML portraying it as being less semantic, and thus not a good choice to use
fwiw, my much more snarky "wannabe" post was set in motion by an XHTML believer complaining about OpenOffice.org's HTML output having upper-case tags
if you look at my latest, you can tell which tags are generated by OO.o and which ones are hand-written in TextWrangler
which is probably horribly untidy

wonders in the polyglot section if I should write down the requirements to have real documents working in the two world. It will be a very tiny subset but that would be interesting at least to set that.
using uppercase tag names is so last century. Lowercase tags are obviously superior
karlcow, in which document are you writing that?
Lachy: it's probably also very uncool to use OO.o to write HTML
jgraham: That sounds like marketing, which is what this is all about
Lachy: http://www.la-grange.net/2009/07/05/html5-xhtml5/ I have not sent it to the WG, but MikeSmith suggested a few fixes.
karlcow: I suggest not having a polyglot section
Using OOo (or MS Word) as a tool to write documents intended to be HTML is bad. But being able to export documents written in those formats to HTML is a good thing, if it gets implemented well
hsivonen: why?

Lachy: I think I'm interested in what the actual real harmful effects of promoting XHTML over HTML are, when it's used as part of the semantic markup marketing platform, because hopefully we could try to minimise similar effects when using HTML5 as part of the rich web application marketing platform
karlcow: if a polyglot section goes up on w3.org, we'll have a generation of gurus telling developers to carefully write polyglot documents without the developers quite understanding why
I already had one comment by mail asking me to develop it further.

Philip`: It seems like people ho are paid to work with HTML should have a better-than-marketing level knowledge of the technology. Being more informed allows them to make more sensible choices about their code
*who
hsivonen: head in the sand?
karlcow: I didn't put my head in sand but instead suggested outright that people not bother with polyglot documents
karlcow: Taking private feedback :)
jgraham: your "should" is not aligned with real world. What I said at the beginning, welcome back to real world

karlcow: In your definition of polyglot documents, should it include a requirement that the syntax is processed in equivalent ways in both HTML and XHTML? e.g. <textarea>[newline]stuff</textarea> is very different in HTML vs XHTML, so it can't be safely used in polyglot documents
oh, nice. I have plans to discuss a lot of those issues in the HTML 5 Reference. Maybe, when you're done, I could incorporate some of that into it
hsivonen: the fact that you can write polyglot documents, makes it a possibility that people will explore. :)
karlcow: So in your real world, the gurus should make up whatever story they think will placate the masses of web developers without worrying about the side effects of people being underinformed?
mouahaha
karlcow: I can already foresee new myths being developed on top of the polyglot concept
we turn into rhetorical manipulation. :) going back to work ;) sorry chaps
karlcow, http://wiki.whatwg.org/wiki/HTML_vs._XHTML lists most of the syntactic differences. I think there was a few small things missing, but I can't recall what they were
Lachy: look at the top of the document
I cite this document
oh
I just saw the table listing syntax differences, and it seemed a little short

jgraham: Seems like division of labour - some people spend years learning all the subtleties of markup syntaxes, and then provide recommendations which can be followed by people who don't want to waste time repeating that whole learning exercise needlessly, and those recommendations necessarily have to summarise and condense and ignore some issues so they can be understood more readily

and I object to you using

as an HTML example of unquoted attributes. Saying it's sloppy seems to convey that it is somehow bad, even though it's a perfectly valid technique
(and hopefully the people providing the recommendations can minimise the harm caused by misinterpretation of the truth)
I would prefer it if documents like this stayed more neutral on the debate about which syntax is better to use, and let authors make a more informed choice
(and those experts would still be expected to justify their arguments in detail if someone asked them about it, so they're not expecting people to blindly rely on their expert status)
Philip`: There is truth in that. In this case I dispute that "XHTML good, HTML bad" (which was roughly the message that many people got) is at the right level of simplicity
the right message that should be conveyed to web developers is that HTML and XHTML are optimised for different requirements, and that authors should choose the one most appropriate for their needs

If people think that quoating their attribute values and closing their tags helps them to write maintainable code then that's a decision that they should be free to make. We should have tools to help them enforce those coding standards. We shouldn't conflate that with pseudo-XHTML
In most cases, given the current browser market, the right choice is generally HTML. But there are legitimate uses for XHTML when done right
jgraham, indeed

jgraham: So it sounds like you agree with the general idea of lying to simple-minded developers, and just have a different view (than people promoting only-XHTML-is-semantic) of whether the harmful consequences of one particular simple lie are unpleasantly (and hopefully avoidably) high
Philip`: I agree that it shouldn't be necessary to know the full detail of the whole language to get started. I wouldn't haracterise that as "lying"

(and of course with the thrd)
web developers don't need to understand the sticks with which they beat each other with, but it helps

and then comes the Black Swan, and your 'web developers' that just follow guidelines and expert counseling are faced to understand the 'display' property and it's values, and how this affects rendering of DIVs, SPANs, and everything
so.. a nice learning path for the very deep details should be offered to them, imho
not to mention the difference it makes when in quirks mode, or when in stric mode, etc.
the most efficient dev teams I've met had zero 'web developers'. They had developers, and graphic designers at the other side, but no glue in between

.

"strict", "transitional", "invalid"

because sometimes, there are things that are often but not universally bad, and the right treatment is a mandatory but nonfatal diagnostic
